docs.lead_paragraph: Every 20 seconds, someone in America is arrested for a drug violation. Every week, on average, a new jail or prison is built to lock up more people in the world's largest penal system. It was not always so. Ten years ago, half as many people were arrested for drug crimes, and the nation's incarceration rate was closer to those of other democracies. But in the 1980's crack cocaine scared the country, and the criminal justice system has never been the same.

headline.main: War on Crack Retreats, Still Taking Prisoners

docs.abstract: Timothy Egan, in first of two articles on crack cocaine, contends that in 1980's crack scared country, and criminal justice system has never been same; crack poisoned many neighborhoods and murder rates rose; for all havoc wreaked by crack, worst fears were not realized; crack appealed mainly to hard-core drug users; number of users began falling not long after surveys began counting them; decade later, violence of crack trade has burned out, and murder rates have plunged; crack left its mark, in ways that few people anticipated; it prompted nation to rewrite drug laws, lock up record number of people and shift money from schools to prisons; its transformed police work, hospitals and courts; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty months ago, after more than a decade on public assistance, Ann McGinniss transformed herself from a welfare mother into a working mother. She now follows the rhythms of suburban parenthood, rising before dawn to prepare her daughter and son for school, then driving from her home in Peekskill, N.Y., to her bookkeeping job at a nearby car dealership.

headline.main: Welfare Policies Alter The Face of Food Lines

docs.abstract: Empty Shelves, first of two articles on growing evidence across nation linking huge drop in food stamp rolls and growing lines at food-charity doors; new welfare policies are swelling lines at soup kitchens and food pantries; some people are working poor caught in middle--new welfare regulations deem them too well off for public assistance, but their pay is not enought to put food on their table; some are immigrants, in US legally but cut off from food stamps under new Federal welfare laws; some seeking food handouts are simply unwilling to deal with hassle or stigma of seeking food stamps in today's anti-welfare climate; together, they are changing face of food lines long occupied by addicted, disabled, and generally down-and-out; photos (L)
